headline.main: Big Brother and the Salt Shaker

docs.abstract: Should government try to monitor and modify how we eat?
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration has announced an initiative to cut salt in packaged and restaurant foods by 25 percent over the next five years. Public health experts say these changes would reduce the incidence of high blood pressure and help prevent some strokes and heart attacks.
docs.snippet: Should government try to monitor and modify how we eat?

headline.main: Good News and Bad News on Food Safety and Health

docs.abstract: The government appoints the first official to oversee all food safety programs. E coli is found at a Toll House cookie factory and obesity rates have leveled off.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has appointed the first official to oversee all the agency's food safety programs. The official, Michael R. Taylor, is deputy commissioner for foods. Legislation expected to pass this spring would give even more power to his office to regulate food safety.
docs.snippet: The government appoints the first official to oversee all food safety programs. E coli is found at a Toll House cookie factory and obesity rates have leveled off.

headline.seo: American Obesity Rates Have Hit Plateau, C.D.C. Data Suggest
headline.print_headline: After a Longtime Rise, Obesity Rates in U.S. Level Off, Data Suggest
headline.main: Obesity Rates Hit Plateau in U.S., Data Suggest

docs.lead_paragraph: The rates for very overweight people have remained constant for at least five years among men and for nearly 10 years among women and children, new numbers indicated.
docs.snippet: The rates for very overweight people have remained constant for at least five years among men and for nearly 10 years among women and children, new numbers indicated.

headline.main: Less Fitness in the U.S. Military

docs.abstract: Has an ever-fatter U.S. population led to a less-fit U.S. military?
docs.lead_paragraph: Over on the "At War" blog, Tim Hsia writes about concerns that an ever-fatter American population has resulted in less-fit recruits to the military.
docs.snippet: Has an ever-fatter U.S. population led to a less-fit U.S. military?

docs.abstract: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on genes and celiac disease.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In previous posts, Dr. Crowe exploredthe varied symptoms of celiac disease and confirming a diagnosis of celiac disease. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers asking about the disease running in families, genetic tests that may help confirm a diagnosis, food allergies and thins that set off the ailment.
docs.snippet: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on genes and celiac disease.

docs.abstract: Rank doesn't matter, nor does it count if your father was a general or a sergeant major: Anyone who reports to his or her unit on Day One in poor physical condition has lost the respect of fellow soldiers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Rank doesn't matter, nor does it count if your father was a general or a sergeant major: Anyone who reports to his or her unit on Day One in poor physical condition has lost the respect of fellow soldiers. One company commander in my previous unit enjoyed testing his new lieutenants with a five-mile run at a blistering pace the day they arrived, followed by pull-ups, push-ups and a gamut of other calisthenics.
docs.snippet: Rank doesn't matter, nor does it count if your father was a general or a sergeant major: Anyone who reports to his or her unit on Day One in poor physical condition has lost the respect of fellow soldiers.

docs.abstract: Given that two of three Americans is overweight, does it matter that the new surgeon general, Dr. Regina M. Benjamin, also struggles with her weight?

headline.sub: Latest Health Initiative Goes Beyond New York  ;
headline.print_headline: Citing Hazard, New York Says Hold the Salt
headline.main: Citing Hazard, New York Says Hold the Salt

docs.lead_paragraph: After initiating prominent campaigns against smoking and harmful trans fats, New York City has a new target: the food industry’s use of salt.
docs.snippet: After initiating prominent campaigns against smoking and harmful trans fats, New York City has a new target: the food industry’s use of salt.

headline.main: A Korean Doctors' Group Wants to Halt Abortions

docs.abstract: Group of South Korean doctors held November news conference to ask forgiveness for performing abortions, which are widespread though generally illegal in South Korea; doctors hope to force first serious public discussion of ethics of procedure; abortion carries little emotional and religious significance in South Korea, but effort is gaining attention as government looks for ways to reverse declining birthrate; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Displaying images of fetuses on her computer screen, Dr. Choi Anna described what happens to them during an abortion. For years, she said, she washed her hands in contrition after each one she performed. Her colleague Dr. Shim Sang-duk said that until it halted the practice in September, their Ion Women's Clinic in Seoul did 30 abortions a month, twice the number of babies delivered there. Nearly all were illegal.
docs.snippet: Displaying images of fetuses on her computer screen, Dr. Choi Anna described what happens to them during an abortion. For years, she said, she washed her hands in contrition after each one she performed.     Her colleague Dr. Shim Sang-duk said that...
